dcterms:title: Nuclear genetic control of mtDNA copy number and heteroplasmy in humans
dcterms:abstract: This study investigates the relationship between nuclear genetic variants and mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) copy number and heteroplasmy in humans. Our analysis of whole-genome sequencing data across large cohorts reveals significant nuclear control over mtDNA traits, uncovering new insights into the genetic architecture that impacts mitochondrial dynamics and their implications for human health.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Introduction
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: Mitochondrial DNA (mtDNA) is a maternally inherited, high-copy-number genome required for oxidative phosphorylation. Heteroplasmy refers to the presence of a mixture of mtDNA alleles in an individual and has been associated with disease and aging.

fabio:hasPart.dcterms:title: Methods
fabio:hasPart.fabio:hasContent: We analyzed whole-genome sequencing data from large biobanks, focusing on the associations between nuclear genetic variants and mtDNA traits.

cito:cites.dcterms:title: Extensive mitochondrial DNA variation across large human populations
Somatic mutations in mitochondrial DNA associated with neurodegenerative diseases
